channel.title: Anyone got a link or know the rsps history?
channel.description:
[b]Well what I really want to know is:[/b] when was the first rsps made (what date and year) what server was the first made the progress throughout the years (how it developed) ect... as much information as possible would be great
why am I asking these questions? you'll find out, small project I'm going to work on

item.title: Anyone got a link or know the rsps history?
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“blakeman8192, post:10, topic:363632”][quote author=the elve age link=topic=459883.msg3380120#msg3380120 date=1287955540]
Blakeman, what makes RuneSource so different?

I can see everything isn’t packaged as much.
[/quote]
It’s a stable, efficient server written from scratch (like Hyperion).
It isn’t extremely complicated/packaged/etc. so less experienced people will be more inclined to use it.[/quote]
May I develop it with you for learning purposes?

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone got a link or know the rsps history?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

The history is very hazy, as Kaitnieks and the other important places in the history of RSPS are now gone.

As far as we know, this is the first RS2 private server ever made: http://www.moparisthebest.com/origrs2/
It was developed by wL, and it’s known commonly as the “winterlove” server base.

After that release, Daiki took it and through lots of research/development, made a multiplayer server called BlakeScape.
BlakeScape is the grandfather of RuneScape private servers.

At that moment, things start to get blurry as dozens of programmers took the original BlakeScape and developed their bases off of it. The main release that emerged from the original BlakeScape was called MythScape. Wolf then took MythScape and built several versions of WhtieScape, which Xerozcheez then used to make Cheezscape. Cheezscape was the dominating server base in the 2007 era, the last version being Cheezscape 80. After this line of servers up to Cheezscape, they were split into three highly popular bases: Project 16, Testscape, and Dodian. Dodian didn’t emerge until later, and originally it was just Project 16 and Testscape for a long time. From Dodian came Devolution, and then DeltaScape (which is currently the most popular server base). From Testscape emerged Pimpscape, which has now died out for the most part.

This flow chart (which Graham made) explains it all well:

If you’re wondering about how well I know this stuff, I’m responsible for the RuneFusion, RuneFusion Final Build, and Enkrona servers on that chart. Enkrona had several versions (2.5, 2.6, and 3.2 I believe were all released to the mainstream) that aren’t mentioned on this chart. Not to toot my own horn, but I’ve also been around RSPS for quite a while now.

Many people have made attempts to re-create the original server base (some examples in chronological order: RuneCore by me and Graham, rs2d by varek, rs2hd by Graham, Hyperion by Graham, 317serv by Yz85Racer, rs377d by me, Apollo by Graham which is not yet released, and I’ve developed several unreleased servers from scratch, including Osiris) with something more stable and efficient than BlakeScape, but most of them have either failed or their server bases have failed to gain mainstream attention. My theory is that their server bases are too complicated for a majority of programmers to use, and hopefully I’ll be solving this problem soon with an open-source server I’ve been working on in my spare time known as RuneSource. It’s meant to resemble the original BlakeScape, but be far more stable, scalable, and efficient.

You can see development on RuneSource here: https://svn.assembla.com/svn/runesource/
I’d like feedback, by the way.

Also, my Osiris 508 server base may be coming out soon through MoparScape, which will be a huge push forward in the 508+ era.
Hopefully that answers some of your questions! I’m glad to see genuine interest in our history.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone got a link or know the rsps history?
